sect3.title: Program Files
sect3.para: c++, c++filt, cc (link to gcc), cc1, cc1plus, collect2, cpp, cpp0, g++, gcc, gcov, protoize and unprotoize

sect4.title: cc, cc1, cc1plus, gcc
sect4.para: These are the C compiler. A compiler translates source code in text format to a format that a computer understands. After a source code file is compiled into an object file, a linker will create an executable file from one or more of these compiler generated object files.

sect4.title: c++, cc1plus, g++
sect4.para: These are the C++ compiler; the equivalent of cc and gcc etc.

sect4.title: c++filt
sect4.para: c++filt is used to demangle C++ symbols.

sect4.title: cpp, cpp0
sect4.para: cpp pre-processes a source file, such as including the contents of header files into the source file. It's a good idea to not do this manually to save a lot of time. Someone just inserts a line like #include <filename>. The preprocessor inserts the contents of that file into the source file. That's one of the things a preprocessor does.

sect4.title: protoize
sect4.para: Optional additional program which converts old-style pre-ANSI functions or definitions to new-style ANSI C prototypes. (default file for looking known ones up is /usr/lib/gcc-lib/<arch>/<version>/SYSCALLS.c.X)

sect4.title: unprotoize
sect4.para: Optional additional program which converts prototypes made by protoize back to original old-style pre-ANSI (correct job only when converted before with protoize)

sect4.title: libgcc
sect4.para: libgcc.a is a run-time support file for gcc.Most of the time, on most machines, libgcc.a is not actually necessary.

sect4.title: libiberty
sect4.para: libiberty is a collection of subroutines used by various GNU programs including getopt, obstack, strerror, strtol and strtoul.

sect4.title: libstdc++
sect4.para: libstdc++ is the C++ library. It is used by C++ programs and contains functions that are frequently used in C++ programs. This way the programmer doesn't have to write certain functions (such as writing a string of text to the screen) from scratch every time he creates a program.
